work.title: Che si può fare?

composer.name: Barbara Strozzi
composer.longDescription: Barbara Strozzi was one of the most prolific female composers of the Baroque era. A singer, composer, and intellectual, she published eight volumes of vocal music, a remarkable achievement for any composer of the time, let alone a woman. Her works are known for their emotional depth, intimate expression, and daring harmonies.
composer.shortDescription: Baroque Venetian composer and singer, renowned for her emotionally charged solo vocal music.

work.shortDescription: A piercing Baroque solo lament transforming helplessness into defiant emotional clarity.
work.longDescription: Che si può fare? is a chamber cantata by Barbara Strozzi, published in 1664. Written for soprano and continuo, the work laments betrayal and abandonment but ultimately asserts emotional agency. Strozzi’s music stretches harmony and time, making sorrow audible and resistance palpable.
work.rawContent:
VOCAL · CHAMBER CANTATA

~6–8 MINUTES

Instrumentation Summary

Soprano & Continuo (typically Theorbo, Harpsichord, Viola da Gamba or Cello)

Mood and Style

Lamenting · Resilient · Intimate

insight: A piercing solo lament that transforms helplessness into power. Strozzi’s vocal line writhes with grief, but never yields. A defiant early cry for agency, it remains strikingly relevant in programs about resistance and emotional survival.

work.title: The Leaden Echo and the Golden Echo

composer.name: Elizabeth Maconchy
composer.longDescription: Elizabeth Maconchy was a major figure in British 20th-century music, known for her uncompromising modernist voice and intellectual rigor. She composed extensively across genres, from string quartets to large-scale vocal works, and was a vocal advocate for women in composition. Her music often grapples with complex emotional and philosophical themes.
composer.shortDescription: British modernist composer known for her expressive power, structural clarity, and philosophical depth.
representativeWorks: The Leaden Echo and the Golden Echo (1978)

work.shortDescription: A radiant and urgent choral meditation on spiritual paradox and emotional renewal.
work.longDescription: Set to Gerard Manley Hopkins’ ecstatic poem, The Leaden Echo and the Golden Echo is a work of dramatic contrast and transformation. Maconchy gives powerful choral voice to the poem’s movement from despair to transcendence, using dense counterpoint, luminous harmonies, and sweeping dynamic arcs. The piece stands as a profound meditation on impermanence and the search for grace.
work.rawContent:
VOCAL · CHOIR & ENSEMBLE

~9 MINUTES

Instrumentation Summary

SSAATTBB Choir, optional chamber instruments or organ

Mood and Style

Urgent · Radiant · Philosophical

insight: Set to Gerard Manley Hopkins’ ecstatic meditation on decay and renewal, this work pulses with shifting energies — a sonic embodiment of inner revolution. Maconchy turns spiritual paradox into dramatic transformation, giving choral voice to the push and pull of despair and hope.
